results.title: The Money Farmers: How Oligarchs and Populists Milk the E.U. for Millions
results.abstract: The European Union spends $65 billion a year subsidizing agriculture. But a chunk of that money emboldens strongmen, enriches politicians and finances corrupt dealing.
results.byline: By SELAM GEBREKIDAN, MATT APUZZO and BENJAMIN NOVAK

results.title: Pénzes gazdák: hogyan fejik meg az Európai Uniót az oligarchák és a populisták.
results.abstract: Az Európai Unió 65 milliárd dollárt költ évente a mezőgazdaság támogatására. Ennek jelentős része kedvez az önkényuraknak, pénzzel tömi a politikusokat, és korrupt ügyeket finanszíroz.
results.byline: By SELAM GEBREKIDAN, MATT APUZZO and BENJAMIN NOVAK

results.title: These Machines Can Put You in Jail. Don’t Trust Them.
results.abstract: Alcohol breath tests, a linchpin of the criminal justice system, are often unreliable, a Times investigation found.
results.byline: By STACY COWLEY and JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG

multimedia.caption: The Dräger Alcotest 9510 and similar devices from other manufacturers are found in police stations across the country. The test results produced by these machines are increasingly drawing skepticism from judges.

results.title: Breath Tests Aim to Stop Drunk Driving. Can We Trust the Results?
results.abstract: Tens of thousands of breath tests in more than a dozen states have been thrown out by judges. What does it mean if we can’t rely on this test?

results.title: Flood of Oil Is Coming, Complicating Efforts to Fight Global Warming
results.abstract: New supplies from Brazil, Canada, Guyana and Norway may add to a glut, posing a threat to producers in Saudi Arabia, Russia and the United States.
org_facet: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries

multimedia.caption: A Norwegian oil platform in the North Sea. Norway’s production has declined for two decades, but its development of the Johan Sverdrup deepwater field should reverse the trend.
